comments.text: Everyone just blindly looking at the price and drooling over it, clearly don't realize the watts difference in these gpu's. 5070 ti averaged well below 300 watts while the 9070xt was edging close to 400 watts numerous times and averaging 345-375 watts.. That price difference in the gpu cost is irrelevant when you're going to need to spend more on a psu to feed the 9070xt power consumption. By the time you're done upgrading to either card, they'll cost the same, give or take, due to amd's high power usage. You guys need to look at the small details, like overall wattage being used, because again, most people will need to upgrade the psu making the $200 +/- price difference useless. If you're current psu needs to be upgraded to run the 9070xt, there goes the $200 offset. AMD is killing it, but they need to get that power efficiency under control.
comments.author: @Alwayspositiveprofits

comments.text:
Imo the 5070ti is the only gpu that is worth it in the 5000 series. The lower ones perform poorly and have only 8/12gb of vram and the higher ones are way overpriced. 

The 9070xt also looks like a great deal. Performance wise theyre mostly identical. If you play Unreal Engine 5 games and rtx demos/remakes and/or use raytracing a lot, go with the 5070ti but if you dont care about these things, the 9070xt might be a better option for you.

These two GPUs seem to be the best of the current generation price-to-performance -wise.

comments.text:
It kind of sucks that many wont ever even think of the horrific thought of getting a gpu like this and dump their money on NVIDIA. The power usage argument wasnt a problem when Intel came out with their 12-14th generation CPUs but suddenly now it matters in order to justify not buying something that gives NVIDIA a run for their money. 

Its stuff like this that keeps us in the GPU hellscape we have today and its really sad. Ruins it for the rest of us who just want competently priced AND performing parts. While yes power efficiency is an obvious plus it shouldnt be a dealbreaker for most people. Seemingly petty things to justify their NVIDIA obsession.

I dont think I even have to speak for the DLSS point that people unfortunately ride too hard. GN/LTT do all the talking there for me. :)

@fabricejaouen378 I cant tell if Im talking to bait or someone stuck in 2017. If its the latter I urge you to update yourself, competition heats up in 2025. :)

And I can tell youve never tried the competition youre so critical of, either. Adrenaline is AMDs driver software, and comes with tuning options thats far nicer to use than afterburner. Very beginner friendly for those wanting to get into the enthusiast space! No extra downloads :)

Ive owned a 1660, 2060, 580, and 7900xtx in my time gaming and can tell you rn later how I feel ab drivers and what GN/LTT see, too. 

P sure even in your productivity workloads you praise nvidia for, Intel still lags behind aside from specific encoding scenarios in every metric. Go ahead by all means but for the context of this argument and best for use case I dont know if you know what youre looking at. TDP for the 285k is 50W lower though Ill give it that

On the driver note, 2017 called and wanted their argument back. AMD have had decent drivers with early adopter hiccups just as nvidia has for years. They get better over time, just like nvidia. Its no different. I own a 7900xtx rn and it performs exactly as advertised and expected, its great!

The whole AI argument here is ignorant af. Yes, theyre ahead and by no means is this a bad choice for those use cases, but discrediting the progress and open source solutions AMD has contributed to the professional space is pretty ignorant, too. I dont blame you buying into nvidia for professional work nonetheless, they do excel there with proprietary solutions they choke the market with. Albeit for far from good value

comments.text:
At maximum performance, the 5070Ti has superior performance and performance per watt, but as we lower the power consumption, we found that at a certain point the 9070XT has significantly better performance than the 5070Ti. All reviewers should mention this: if you limit the 9070XT to 220W, it will outperform a 5070Ti at the same power consumption by a huge margin. Amazing fact. The sweet spot for the RX9070XT is 220W. At this power consumption, the 9070XT far surpasses all other GPUs, including the 5070Ti, making it a performance-per-watt monster. Also, I probably shouldn't say this too much, but if you compare at 220W, the 9070XT outperforms the 9070. There's no point in buying the 9070 XD
Please keep this comment in mind. You will understand what I mean when you use the 9070XT at -150mV. More details can be found on the website computerbase.de.

340w vs 240w
You will pay way more for your AMD

comments.text:
You have to factor in the ACTUAL price though. Not MSRP. To Nvidia, MSRP means "Missing Some Rops Probably". 

For instance the 4090 vs 7900XTX was "supposed" to be 999 vs 1399, right? And given the Nvidia card was 25-30% faster, it was pretty close in competition.

But in REALITY, the 4090 spent the majority of it's shelf life at OVER 2000! With many models here in the UK being 2200 for months and months, while the 7900XTX was sitting at around 800. That means you could almost buy THREE 7900XTXs for the price of a single 4090...........

Imagine paying 250% more money for just 30% more performance, and thinking you got a good deal! XD

It's like buying 6 apples for 20, instead of 5 apples for 8, and saying "I'm SMART cos I GOT MORE APPLES!".

comments.text: @deathstroke1130And? What does the 5070 have in store for me? Ray Tracing that will become obsolete in a year due to its low VRAM? MFG that will also become obsolete due to low VRAM? Hell, I doubt that it would be able to run at max textures at 1440p in a few years. GDDR7 memory is nice but faster speed doesn't mean that it can compensate for it's lack of space. Look at the 3070 and 6700 XT for example, the 3070 is faster but due to its lower VRAM, we have to literally go to medium or high settings to run the game while the 6700 XT can still do ultra textures at 1440p. Ray Tracing is a feature that can be used only when there's enough VRAM, something that the 5070 doesn't have. The 5070 Ti is priced so high that I might as well consider it as a 80 class card due to it being incredibly close to the 5080 in performance and pricing seems accurate for that range. The 9070 XT is competing with the 5070 due to them being priced very close to each other and there's no doubt which one is better. Nvidia has always tried to kill and sabotage their own GPUs with low VRAM. The only thing Nvidia has going for them is DLSS and AMD is even starting to clash blows in image quality and even manages to win against DLSS 4 in certain cases from what LTT has said about it. AMD is finally using AI in their FSR 4 and looks to be catching up with Nvidia. It's a no brainier for me to buy a 9070 XT instead of a 5070 that will become obsolete in a year or so.

History shows that AMD has previously stated it would focus on specific market segments, only to later return to compete in the high-end category when the technology and market conditions were right. comments.text:
@lacm81 Absolutely, thats exactly why AMD waits for the right moment to release their products. They understand the market dynamics and know that releasing high-end cards too early can be a risk if consumers aren't ready to support them. Its a strategic approach where they have to release competitive products, like the 9070 XT and gauge consumer interest to see if people are willing to buy.

At least AMD doesnt give up. Intel didnt take AMD seriously enough, and now theyre struggling, nearly on the brink of bankruptcy. NVIDIA hasnt taken AMD seriously either and has become overly confident in their position.

comments.text:
At maximum performance, the 5070Ti has superior performance and performance per watt, but as we lower the power consumption, we found that at a certain point the 9070XT has significantly better performance than the 5070Ti. All reviewers should mention this: if you limit the 9070XT to 220W, it will outperform a 5070Ti at the same power consumption by a huge margin. Amazing fact. The sweet spot for the RX9070XT is 220W. At this power consumption, the 9070XT far surpasses all other GPUs, including the 5070Ti, making it a performance-per-watt monster. Also, I probably shouldn't say this too much, but if you compare at 220W, the 9070XT outperforms the 9070. There's no point in buying the 9070 XD
Please keep this comment in mind. You will understand what I mean when you use the 9070XT at -150mV. More details can be found on the website computerbase.de. Frankly speaking, this is shocking. I want you to spread this information. Geforce completely loses to Radeon in the battle of energy saving settings. It's not even a match.
@Jutepest Undervolting is common practice, standard among anyone with tech knowledge. You should research and experiment more before acting like you know anything.

It is pretty clear Nvidia are getting complacent in the consumer side and I doubt they will care unless amd bring a card that rivals the 5080 or 5090 in raw performance because they know people will buy their card because it's the most powerful in the current market regardless how overpriced it is.

Guys, it's very interesting to know how AMD is developing. AMD claims to have doubled RT performance in the new generation. It's not about games, it's about improvement. 

AMD is always behind Nvidia, but at the same time they always try to offer the best product in terms of price-performance ratio. It's like the news that Nvidia's latest line doesn't work with PhysX in older games. 

I have an RTX 4060 for gaming, but it's also good to keep an eye on the opposition.

@-8 Who cares about RT?

DEVELOPERS dont care, about RT. Less than 2% of ALL GAMES released in the year 2024 on PC on STEAM .... had RT features or implementation.

18 months after RT was launched with Turing, there were less than 30 RT games in existance. Jensen promised 120+ the reality was less than 30.

Only top end stupidly high prices flagship GPU's can do RT effectively, from Turing and Ampere and Lovelace etc, with the entry level cards incapable and the mid range cards needing to upscale from 1080p or even 720p (a resolution from the mid 2000's).

Consoles can't do RT. Cos they don't HAVE stupidly high end expensive GPU's in them.

ERGO .... developers dont care about RT. Neither do MOST gamers. Cos it's a gimmick, and WILL be a gimmick until ENTRY LEVEL CARDS (and consoles) CAN DO IT! And I dont mean shiny floors and puddles. I mean true RT like we saw in the Quake II RTX. But thats a 30+ year old game, which runs at 6000fps on modern systems. You WONT GET THOSE RT EFFECTS in modern games, cos even a 5090 would give single digit performance in 1080p in this situation.

comments.text:
At maximum performance, the 5070Ti has superior performance and performance per watt, but as we lower the power consumption, we found that at a certain point the 9070XT has significantly better performance than the 5070Ti. All reviewers should mention this: if you limit the 9070XT to 220W, it will outperform a 5070Ti at the same power consumption by a huge margin. Amazing fact. The sweet spot for the RX9070XT is 220W. At this power consumption, the 9070XT far surpasses all other GPUs, including the 5070Ti, making it a performance-per-watt monster. Also, I probably shouldn't say this too much, but if you compare at 220W, the 9070XT outperforms the 9070. There's no point in buying the 9070.
Please keep this comment in mind. You will understand what I mean when you use the 9070XT at -150mV. More details can be found on the website computerbase.de.
